title: 5 Things To Know: June 9, 2025
content:
All right, five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. President Trump's top trade officials are meeting their Chinese counterparts in London today. That includes Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, and US Trade Representative Jameson Greer. The talks come as new data from China overnight showed a 34 and a half% drop in exports from China to the US in May. And domestic prices continue to be a concern, China's CPI declined for a fourth consecutive month.

In the meantime, a US trade team that's currently in India for negotiations has extended its stay. That's according to a Bloomberg report that says that the talks were scheduled for last Thursday and Friday, but they will continue through Tuesday in a sign that the negotiations are progressing. And back here in the United States, President Trump said that his pick for the next Fed chair will be coming very soon. When asked if the choice might be former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh, the president didn't tip his hand, but he did say that Warsh in his words is fairly, very highly thought of. Trump made those comments to reporters on Air Force One on Friday evening.

And a long-awaited decision for college athletes was approved late Friday. A federal judge signed off on a $2.6 billion settlement that paves the way for direct payments from universities to players. It creates a system where each division one school will be able to distribute roughly $20 million per year to their athletes. It launches college sports into a new era that will funnel billions of dollars of revenue generating sports like football and basketball, but it could jeopardize sports programs that don't bring in money, especially at smaller schools.

So it's less than a year now for Jay Powell.
Yeah, it's 2026, is it? May, May of 2026.
So that's why we're talking about this. Yeah, not going to replace him.
Not back with that.
No, scuttlebutt, right? It's just when it happens. Right. Who it would be.
Interesting.
Warsh is...
I can't imagine he'd be lowering rates necessarily.
No. Um, but he's also somebody who, uh, has been very close with the administration.
I know, but if you're looking for someone who's going to... Are you looking for somebody who's just going to cut rates or are you looking for somebody who's going to make sure that you don't up?
He could, I, I think of him almost as just a- there's been times when he's wanted Jay Powell to do even more hawkish things than, than what Jay Powell. I don't know how that would work.
summary:
The market outlook ahead of the opening bell highlights key developments in international trade and domestic policy. President Trump's top trade officials, including Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, and US Trade Representative Jameson Greer, are currently in London meeting with Chinese counterparts. These discussions follow recent data from China indicating a significant 34.5% drop in exports to the US in May and a fourth consecutive month of decline in China's Consumer Price Index (CPI), raising concerns about domestic prices.

Simultaneously, a US trade team in India has extended its negotiations, originally scheduled for last Thursday and Friday, through Tuesday. This extension, reported by Bloomberg, suggests positive progress in the talks. Domestically, President Trump confirmed an imminent announcement for his next Fed chair pick, hinting at former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh as a highly regarded candidate, despite Warsh's potentially more hawkish stance compared to current Fed Chair Jay Powell.

In collegiate sports, a landmark federal judge's approval of a $2.6 billion settlement late Friday will enable direct payments from universities to athletes. This decision allows Division I schools to distribute approximately $20 million annually to their athletes, ushering in a new era for college sports. While it promises to channel billions into revenue-generating sports like football and basketball, there's concern it could jeopardize funding for non-revenue sports, particularly at smaller institutions. The discussion also touched upon the timing of the Fed chair announcement, noting Jay Powell's term extends until May 2026.

key_points.text: President Trump's trade officials are in London for talks with Chinese counterparts.
The US delegation includes Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
The US delegation includes Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
The US delegation includes US Trade Representative Jameson Greer.
New data revealed a 34.5% drop in China's exports to the US in May.
China's domestic prices are a concern as CPI declined for the fourth consecutive month.
A US trade team in India has extended its stay for ongoing negotiations.
Bloomberg reported the extension of the US-India trade talks.
The India talks were initially scheduled for last Thursday and Friday.
Negotiations in India will now continue through Tuesday.
The extension of talks signifies progress in negotiations with India.
President Trump announced that his choice for the next Fed chair is imminent.
Kevin Warsh, a former Fed Governor, is a potential candidate for Fed Chair.
President Trump holds Kevin Warsh in very high regard.
Trump's comments about the Fed chair selection were made on Air Force One.
The comments were made to reporters on Friday evening.
A significant decision regarding college athletes was approved late Friday.
A federal judge approved a $2.6 billion settlement for college athletes.
The settlement allows for direct payments from universities to players.
A system is created for Division I schools to distribute funds to athletes.
Division I schools can distribute approximately $20 million per year to their athletes.
The settlement marks a new era for college sports.
Billions of dollars will be funneled into revenue-generating sports.
Sports like football and basketball are expected to benefit from new revenue streams.
The settlement could negatively impact non-revenue generating sports programs.
Smaller schools are particularly at risk for their non-revenue sports programs.
Jay Powell's term as Fed Chair is approaching its end.
Jay Powell's term extends until May 2026.
Speculation surrounds the potential replacement for Jay Powell.
Kevin Warsh is not expected to necessarily advocate for lowering interest rates.
Kevin Warsh has maintained a close relationship with the current administration.
There's a debate on whether the next Fed chair should focus on cutting rates.
Kevin Warsh has previously favored more hawkish monetary policies than Jay Powell.
